To solve the problem of low selectivity of methanol conversion products and high energy barrier of initial methanol dehydrogenation in the CH3OH to CHOOCH3 reaction, a series of M-C59 (Fe-C59, Co-C59, Ni-C59, and Cu-C59) catalysts were constructed. Molecular dynamics simulations show that M-C59 catalysts have high stability. Based on density functional theory (DFT), the relevant data of each elementary reaction is calculated in detail, and the mechanism of direct dehydrogenation of CH3OH to CHOOCH3 is systematically discussed. The results show that Cu-C59 catalyst has higher selectivity of methyl formate and lower energy barrier of initial methanol dehydrogenation, and Cu-C59 exhibits highest activity for forming CHOOCH3. Moreover, it is observed that β(LUMOHOMO)gap energy of M-C59 catalysts can serve as a descriptor for CHOOCH3 formation activity. The models and calculation results established in this paper provide a valuable reference for the design and development of nanocatalysts. Graphical abstract In this work, the metal types affect the activity and selectivity of CH3OH to CHOOCH3, the β(LUMOHOMO) gap energy can be utilized as a descriptor for the difficulty of converting methanol to methyl formate on M-C59 catalysts. Among them, the Cu-C59 exhibits highest activity and selectivity for forming CHOOCH3. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Methanol Methyl formate Single-atom DFT M-C59 Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Methanol, as a clean energy source, can be derived from various sources such as coal, oil, and natural gas. The production of methanol has been steadily increasing year by year, resulting in an excess of methanol capacity [1]. To effectively address this surplus, it is essential to develop a diversified downstream technology roadmap for methanol. Methanol has versatile applications in the production of aldehydes, ethers, alcohols, esters, olefins and other chemical products. Among these various products, methyl formate plays a crucial role in C1 chemistry and can be utilized as a refrigerant, foaming agent, and fuel additive [2]. The production of methyl formate involves methanol conversion technology, which mainly includes esterification of methanol with formic acid [3], methanol carbonylation [4], direct dehydrogenation of methanol [5], selective oxidative dehydrogenation of methanol [6], and carbon dioxide hydrogenation-condensation with methanol [7]. Among these methods, the direct dehydrogenation of methanol to methyl formate is considered an efficient and cost-effective process. This is due to its use of a single raw material and simple operation, making it worthy of further development and utilization [5,8]. In recent years, transition metal copper has emerged as an ideal catalyst for methanol dehydrogenation to methyl formate due to its affordability, wide availability, and exceptional catalytic activity. Previous experimental findings have indicated that Cu-supported catalysts such as Cu/SiO2 [9],Cu/MgO [10], and Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 [11] exhibit high methanol conversion activity but low selectivity towards methyl formate. Theoretical studies have suggested that modified Cu-based catalyst demonstrates high selectivity for methyl formate; however, the energy barrier for initial methanol dehydrogenation is substantial, thereby limiting methanol activation [12]. Therefore, it is crucial to develop a unique Cu-based catalyst with both high selectivity for methyl formate and a low energy barrier for initial methanol dehydrogenation in order to design effective catalysts for the conversion of methanol into methyl formate. Modifying the coordination environment of Cu is an effective strategy for optimizing catalytic performance. The studies show that the interaction between carbon materials and metals can effectively improve the catalytic performance of methanol conversion reaction [13], and the copper-carbon composite can stabilize Cu particles [14]. As a new class of catalysts, especially transition metal monoatoms embedded in carbon nanomaterials (M-C) , single-atom catalysts have attracted much attention due to their maximum atomic utilization efficiency and improved catalytic performance [15-17]. As a common carbon nanomaterial, C60 plays an important role in various catalytic reactions [18,19]. In summary, the embedding of single metal atoms into C60 (M-C59) as a catalyst is expected to improve the activity and selectivity of methanol conversion, while stabilizing the metal particles. In this study, four types of metal-modified C60 catalysts, labeled M-C59 (M=Fe, Co, Ni, Cu), were designed and their catalytic properties were systematically studied based on density functional theory (DFT). The thermal stability of the catalysts, the reaction mechanism of CH3OH to CHOOCH3 on M-C59 catalysts, and the formation of CO by-products were explored. The effects of micro-factors such as charges and gap energies on the adsorption, activation and transformation of methanol were elucidated. The results obtained can offer theoretical guidance for similar reactions and catalytic systems. 2 Computational details 2.1 Calculation methods All calculations were performed using the Vienna ab-initio simulation package (VASP 6.3) with a DFT method incorporating spin polarization [20-22]. Projector-augmented wave (PAW) pseudopotentials were employed to describe the interaction between core electrons [23], and the dispersion effect was described using the DFT-D3 method [24]. For structural optimization, the force on each atom of the catalyst was less than 0.02 eV‧Å-1. The plane wave basis set with a cut-off energy of 400 eV was utilized, and a standard Monkhorst–Pack grid sampling with a 1 × 1 × 1 k-point mesh was employed. The transition state (TS) was determined using the climbing-image nudged elastic band (CI-NEB) method [25]. The residual force for transition state calculation was set to 0.03 eV‧Å-1, and each transition state was verified by vibrational analysis with only one imaginary frequency. The ab initio molecular dynamics (AIMD) [26] simulation was performed at 500 K with 10,000 steps and 1 fs time steps in NVT ensemble. The adsorption free energies (Gads) [27,28] is defined as follows: (1) G a d s = ( E a d s o r b a t e / s u b + G a d s o r b a t e / s u b ) − ( E a d s o r b a t e + G a d s o r b a t e ) − ( E s u b + G s u b ) where Eadsorbate/sub is the total energy of the adsorbed species and the substrate, Eadsorbate is the energy of the adsorbate species in the gas, and Esub is the energy of the clean substrate. Gadsorbate/sub, Gadsorbate and Gsub are the corresponding free energy corrections at 500 K. The reaction free energies (∆G) [27,28] and activation free energies (Ga) [27,28] are calculated according by the following equations: (2) Δ G = ( E F S + G F S ) − ( E I S + G I S ) (3) G a = ( E T S + G T S ) − ( E I S + G I S ) Where EIS, ETS and EFS correspond to the total energies of initial state (IS), TS and final state (FS), respectively; GIS, GTS and GFS are the corresponding free energy corrections at 500 K. When the structure of IS, TS and FS is determined, various thermodynamic data such as enthalpy (H), entropy (S) and free energy (G) can be obtained by a vibrational analysis calculation. In this work, The free energy correction was analyzed based on the VASP toolkit (vaspkit) [29]. Based on the transition state theory [30], the formula for calculating the reaction rate constant is as follows: (4) k = k B T h e x p ( − G a k B T ) In the formula, Ga is activation free energy, h is Planck's constant, kB is Boltzmann's constant, T is common reaction temperature (500 K) [31,32]. The formula for calculating the charge density difference is as follows [33]: (5) Δ ρ = ρ A B − ρ A − − ρ B Here, ρAB represents the structural charge density after interface optimization, while ρA and ρB represent the charge densities of A and B, respectively. According to formula, the charge density change after A and B form AB can be analyzed. 2.2 Calculation models The stable configurations of the M-C59 (Fe-C59, Co-C59, Ni-C59 and Cu-C59) catalyst models selected in this work are illustrated in Fig. 1 . Additionally, Fig. 1 presents the charge distribution on M-C59 catalysts, and it is found that the metal loses electrons, its coordination carbon atoms gain electrons, and the remaining carbon atoms gain and lose electrons is not obvious. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Property calculation The results indicate that the catalytic activity is related to the magnetic properties of metals [34,35], and calculating the properties of catalysts is conducive to more accurate study of the microscopic mechanism. Fig. 2 illustrates the energy levels of M-C59 at different spin states (nα - nβ from 0 to 10). The findings reveal that the most stable spin states of Fe-C59, Co-C59, Ni-C59 and Cu-C59 are 0, 1, 0 and 1, respectively. Table 1 presents the highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) energies and lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO) energies corresponding to the spin states (α and β) of M -C59 with their respective gap energies. The difference between alpha LUMO and HOMO gap energy (α(LUMO−HOMO) gap energy) of Fe-C59, Co-C59, Ni-C59 and Cu-C59 are 0.68, 0.75, 0.58 and 0.18 eV, respectively, and difference between beta LUMO and HOMO gap energy (β(LUMOHOMO) gap energy) are 0.68, 0.99, 0.58 and 0.47 eV, respectively. 3.2 Stability calculation To verify the thermodynamic stability of the M-C59 catalysts, molecular dynamics simulations were conducted. A simulation lasted 10 ps at 500 K, with a time step of 10,000 steps and 1 fs. As depicted in Fig. 3 , the energy fluctuated within a small range during the simulation, and no significant structural changes were observed. These results indicate that M-C59 catalysts exhibit thermodynamic stability at 500 K. 3.3 Adsorption behavior of methanol and related species To consider the dehydrogenation of methanol on M-C59 catalysts, adsorption behavior of methanol and related species (CH3O, CH2O, CHO, CO, and CHOOCH3) was investigated. The adsorption free energies of these species are presented in Table 2 , with the most stable optimized geometries depicted in Fig. S1. The adsorption free energies of CH3OH range from −0.17 to 0.16 eV on M-C59 catalysts. To thoroughly explore the origin of CH3OH activation, the activation process of CH3OH on M-C59 catalysts was investigated from three aspects: energy, geometry, and electronic structure. Previous studies have indicated that the weak adsorption of O2 on the Fe-N4 site is crucial for enhancing its ORR activity [36]. The adsorption energy is influenced by electron transfer between the molecule and the surface. Here, the adsorption mechanism is elucidated by analyzing the electron transfer related to adsorption energy, specifically focusing on the correlation between adsorption energy and electron transfer between the catalyst and adsorbed molecule. The activation of methanol begins with its adsorption. To investigate the interaction between CH3OH molecules and M-C59 catalysts, the charge density difference and bader charge were studied. The Fig. 4 illustrates the charge density difference of CH3OH molecules adsorbed on M-C59 catalysts, with blue and yellow indicating charge loss and accumulation, respectively. It is evident that a significant charge transfer occurs between CH3OH molecules and M-C59 catalysts. Further Bader charge analysis revealed that CH3OH transferred 0.092, 0.082, 0.075, and 0.080 electrons to Fe-C59, Co-C59, Ni-C59 and Cu-C59 catalysts, respectively. Fig. 5 (a) clearly illustrates the correlation (y = 18.99x + 1.56, R2=0.97) between the number of electrons transferred from methanol to the catalysts and adsorption free energies. This suggests that the number of transferred electrons from methanol can serve as a descriptor for the adsorption free energy. 3.4 Reaction mechanism As depicted in Fig. 6 , CHOOCH3 can be synthesized through three pathways by intermediates (Path1, Path2 and Path3) [12,37]. These pathways include (1) dehydrogenation after coupling reaction of CH2O and CH3O, (2) dimerization reaction of CH2O, and (3) direct coupling reaction by CHO and CH3O. Among them processes, the activation and dehydrogenation of methanol, as well as the CO coupling reaction, are involved. 3.4.1 Activation of methanol The activation of methanol represents the initial stage in the process of methanol conversion, and is widely recognized as a crucial step in the overall reaction. As shown in Table 3 , the activation free energies for methanol dehydrogenation (R1) on Fe-C59, Co-C59, Ni-C59 and Cu-C59 catalysts are 0.87, 0.58, 0.16 and 0.22 eV, respectively. Except Fe-C59 catalyst, the activation free energies of methanol initial cracking on other catalysts are lower than that of metal catalysts [12,38,39]. Fig. 5(b) demonstrates the correlation (y = −43.75x−3.14, R2=0.89) between the number of electrons transferred from methanol to the catalysts and the activation free energies of the initial cracking. The weak electron interaction between catalyst and reactant solves the problem of high adsorption strength and thus improves the catalytic activity. This suggests that the number of transferred electrons from methanol can be used as a descriptor for the activation free energy, indicating its potential significance in predicting the activation of methanol. Similar to other findings [36 , 40], charge transfer between the catalytic site and the reactant molecule can regulate activity and has been used as a descriptor of the catalyst, and this correlation between the electrons on the catalyst and the adsorption strength of the adsorbent justifies the strategy of regulating catalytic activity by electron transfer. In addition, previous studies have shown that catalytic performance depends on a range of structural parameters, and molecular bond length, as another important descriptor, is crucial in quantifying the structure-property relationship and guiding the rational design of catalysts. Ghani et al. [41]. observed that the double bond of the O2 molecule, originally measuring 1.21 Å, was elongated to 1.45 Å upon adsorption on defective TiS2. This elongation indicates a weakening of the OO bond, which facilitates the catalytic reaction due to this reduced bond strength. These results indicate that the catalytic activity can be evaluated by the bond length of adsorbed molecules. As shown in Fig. 4, when CH3OH were adsorbed on M-C59, the OH bond lengths measured 0.973, 0.974, 0.976, and 0.976 Å, respectively. These values were longer than the OH bond length observed in the gas phase, indicating that the OH bond is activated. The different activation free energy of the OH bond cleavage in CH3OH on M-C59 catalysts is attributed to the different activation degree (lengths of adsorbed OH bonds). The correlation (Fig. 7 (a)) between the OH bond length in the adsorbed state and the corresponding activation free energy is expressed as y =−219.63x + 214.54 (R2=0.99). 3.4.2 Subsequent cracking of methanol On Fe-C59 catalyst, the decomposition pathway of CH3O to CO is as follows: R2→R3→R4, with corresponding activation free energies of 1.31, 1.60, and 0.29 eV, respectively. The rate-limiting step is R3, which has an activation free energy of 1.60 eV The decomposition pathway of CH3O to CO on Co-C59, Ni-C59, and Cu-C59 catalysts is identical to that on Fe-C59 catalyst. On Co-C59 catalyst, the activation free energies for each elementary reaction of CH3O and CO are 1.64, 1.49, and 0.14 eV, respectively. The rate-limiting step is R2, which has an activation free energy of 1.64 eV On Ni-C59 catalyst, the activation free energies for each elementary reaction of CH3O and CO are 1.27, 1.38, and 0.76 eV, respectively. The rate-limiting step is R3, which has an activation free energy of 1.38 eV On Cu-C59 catalyst, the activation free energies for each elementary reaction of CH3O and CO are 1.02, 1.69, and 1.43 eV, respectively. The rate-limiting step is R3, which has an activation free energy of 1.69 eV The activation free energies of the rate-limiting steps for the conversion of CH3OH to CO on Fe-C59, Co-C59, Ni-C59 and Cu-C59 catalysts are 1.60, 1.64, 1.38 and 1.69 eV, respectively (refer to Table 3). Compared to the literature, the activation free energies for CO generation on M-C59 catalysts are slightly higher than that of other catalysts [38,39]. The corresponding rate constants are 7.76 × 10–4, 3.07 × 10–4, 1.28 × 10–1, and 9.61 × 10–5 s-1, respectively (refer to Table 4 ). 3.4.3 CO coupling reactions The CO coupling reactions involve Path1 (R5, R6), Path2 (R7), and Path3 (R8). The optimal pathway for CO coupling is determined by calculating and comparing the activation free energies of the elementary reactions corresponding to the three paths. On Fe-C59 catalyst, the activation free energies of the elementary reactions (R5-R8) are 0.98, 0.86, 1.16, and 2.03 eV, respectively. On Co-C59 catalyst, the activation free energies of the elementary reactions (R5-R8) are 1.11, 0.63, 1.30, and 1.81 eV, respectively. On Ni-C59 catalyst, the activation free energies of the elementary reactions (R5-R8) are 1.15, 0.62, 2.32, and 1.83 eV, respectively. On Cu-C59 catalyst, the activation free energies of the elementary reactions (R5-R8) are 1.26, 0.40, 2.37, and 2.65 eV, respectively. On M-C59 catalysts, the activation free energies for the elementary reaction R5 are lower compared to R7 and R8. Therefore, the preferred pathway for the formation of CHOOCH3 is through the indirect pathway (Path1), specifically CH2O+CH3O→CH2OOCH3→CHOOCH3+H, which is consistent with previous study findings [12,37]. 3.4.4 General discussion The most optimal pathways for the production of CHOOCH3 from CH3OH on M-C59 catalysts are R1, R2, R5, and R6. The activation free energies of the rate-limiting steps for the conversion of CH3OH to CHOOCH3 on Fe-C59, Co-C59, Ni-C59 and Cu-C59 catalysts are 1.31, 1.64, 1.27 and 1.26 eV, respectively (refer to Table 3). The corresponding rate constants are 6.50 × 10–1, 3.07 × 10–4, 1.65 × 10°, and 2.08 × 10° s-1, respectively (refer to Table 4). Except for Co-C59 catalyst, the preferred product on the other three catalysts is CHOOCH3, whose corresponding activation free energies are similar to those of most catalysts [12,37,42]. We speculate that the simultaneous formation of CHOOCH3 and CO on Co-C59 catalyst may be attributed to the influence of metal type on the adsorption stability of CH3O on M-C59 catalysts. The stable adsorption of CH3O (−2.30 eV) on Co-C59 catalyst results in a high cleavage energy barrier, thereby leading to the concurrent generation of CHOOCH3 and CO. It can be seen that the metal types affect the activity and selectivity of methanol to methyl formate. Among them, Cu-C59 is an effective catalyst for CH3OH to CHOOCH3 due to its high selectivity and low initial energy barrier of methanol dehydrogenation. Fig. 7(b) illustrates the correlation (R2=0.99) between the β(LUMOHOMO) gap energies and activation free energies for the conversion of methanol to methyl formate in the rate-limiting step. The β HOMO and LUMO orbital diagrams are shown in Fig. S6. This indicates that the β(LUMOHOMO) gap energy can serve as a descriptor for the activation free energy of the rate-limiting step, suggesting its potential significance in predicting the conversion of methanol to methyl formate. 4 Conclusions In this study, to solve the problem of catalysts in the CH3OH to CHOOCH3 reaction, M-C59 catalysts are designed and their catalytic properties are systematically studied by DFT. The results show that the metal types affect the activity and selectivity of CH3OH to CHOOCH3. The preferred product is CHOOCH3 on Fe-C59, Ni-C59 and Cu-C59 catalysts, while CHOOCH3 and CO are formed almost simultaneously on Co-C59 catalysts. Among them, Cu-C59 catalyst has higher stability, higher selectivity of methyl formate and lower initial energy barrier of methanol dehydrogenation. Moreover, Cu-C59 exhibits the highest catalytic activity, with the active free energy and rate constant of 1.26 eV and 2.08 × 10° s-1, respectively, and the corresponding β(LUMOHOMO) gap energy of 0.47 eV Additionally, the β(LUMOHOMO) gap energy can be utilized as a descriptor for the difficulty of converting methanol to methyl formate on M-C59 catalysts. The models and calculation results established in this paper provide a valuable reference for the design and development of novel nanocatalysts, and they also play a role in predicting the catalytic performance to a certain extent. coredata.dc:description: To solve the problem of low selectivity of methanol conversion products and high energy barrier of initial methanol dehydrogenation in the CH3OH to CHOOCH3 reaction, a series of M-C59 (Fe-C59, Co-C59, Ni-C59, and Cu-C59) catalysts were constructed. Molecular dynamics simulations show that M-C59 catalysts have high stability. Based on density functional theory (DFT), the relevant data of each elementary reaction is calculated in detail, and the mechanism of direct dehydrogenation of CH3OH to CHOOCH3 is systematically discussed. The results show that Cu-C59 catalyst has higher selectivity of methyl formate and lower energy barrier of initial methanol dehydrogenation, and Cu-C59 exhibits highest activity for forming CHOOCH3. Moreover, it is observed that β(LUMOHOMO)gap energy of M-C59 catalysts can serve as a descriptor for CHOOCH3 formation activity. The models and calculation results established in this paper provide a valuable reference for the design and development of nanocatalysts.
